chunks.original_text: 不辨五行四象，那分朱汞铋银，抽添火候未曾闻，早便称呼居隐。 不解自思己错，更将错路教人，误他永世在迷津，似怠欺心安忍。 五行者，金、木、水、火、土也。 四象者，青龙、白虎、朱雀、玄武也。 朱汞者，砂中取汞也。 铅银者，铅中取银也。 火候者，真阳之火、节符之候也。 平叔谓学者妄乱以肺为金，以肝为木，以肾为水，以心为火，以脾为土。 又以肝属青龙，肺属白虎，心属朱雀，肾属玄武。 此为五行、四象，修炼金丹，可谓无所辨别，那分朱汞、铅银。 亦非拾一身之外而别谓五行四象，譬之铅砂为有质之物，五脏亦有质之形，如何可以成道。 惟於有形质之中，而得其无形质之用，则自粗造精，超凡入圣，始得铅汞之秘矣。 虽然纵识朱砂及黑铅，不知火侯也如闲。 况不识不解，而错以教人，所谓迷迷相引，无有出期，如此用心，尚安忍哉。 西江月 天地才经否泰，朝昏要识屯蒙。 辐来凑毂水朝宗，妙在抽添运用。 得一万般事毕，休分南北西东。 损之又损慎前功，命宝不宜轻弄。 天地交而为泰，是上阴下阳也。 不交而为否，是上阳下阴也。 云雷屯，君子以经纶，是物之屯难始生，不可栈贼也。 山下出泉，蒙，君子以果行育德，是泉之始达，当蒙以养正也。 即此四卦之义，托喻金丹，正合其宜。 或者以六十卦分为三十日，以乾、坤、坎、离四卦为炉鼎，抑何穿凿牵强也。 殊不知一阴一阳之谓道否、泰、屯、蒙之谓功。 以金丹言之，全在阴阳交媾之精。 傥若天自天地自地，否塞不通，不能交而为泰，则阴阳何以为道，大药何以成丹。 至於朝屯暮蒙，即是谨於持守，常若屯难养蒙之时，不可一念差失，不可一时恣纵，戒谨乎所不睹，恐惧乎所不闻，实不忘於朝昏顷刻间也。 若能如此修为，则辐来奏毂，如车之运行，初无败阙。 如水之流转，万折必东。 故真一先天之气机缄相应，符节不爽。 抽添运用，妙斡天机。 得此真一命宝，当持盈守成而矣。 抱朴子曰：人能守一，一能守人。 人不能守一，一能去人。 岂非命宝不宜轻弄乎。 西江月 冬至一阳来复，三旬增一阳爻，月中复卦朔晨超，望罢乾终变妮。 日又别为寒暑，阳生复起中宵，午时娠象一阴朝，炼药方知昏晓。 一年有三百六十日，以六阴六阳盈亏消长攒簇於爻象之间，有年中冬至，月中冬至，日中冬至。 六位相乘，片阳相荡，十二卦备，则天道明而周天火候足矣。 且年中冬至阳生於子，是十一月用地雷复 卦为一阳爻。 十二月建在丑，用地泽临 卦为二阳爻。 正月建在寅，用地天泰 卦为三阳爻。 每月三十日换一卦，以进火符，是三旬增一阳爻，乃一年卦气周天之侯也。 夫攒年簇月为月中冬至者，以一月三十日，一日十二时，共得三百六十时耶，准一年三百六十日，却以初一日为复卦，每二日半共坎卦，至十五为乾 纯阳卦。 然阳极则阴生，至十六日为望，用天风姤 卦以退火符，乃阴长阳消。 所谓望罢乾终变姤，乃一月日卦数准一年周天之侯也。 若夫攒年簇日为日中冬至者，以一日十二时分为阴阳升降之节，以子初阳生为冬至，以午后阴生为夏至。 亦以一时辰为一卦，用复姤进退阴阳之始也，用乾坤变化阴阳之终也。 昼夜循环於百刻之内，以时易日法神功，亦象一年卦数周天之候也。
chunks.translated_text:
Without discerning the Five Phases and Four Images,
how can one distinguish cinnabar-mercury from lead-silver?
Unversed in the art of fire-timing and withdrawal-addition,
one prematurely styles oneself a recluse.

Failing to reflect on one’s own errors,
one further teaches these mistaken paths to others,
leading them astray for generations in the maze of delusion—
how can such negligence bear the weight of conscience?

The Five Phases are Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth.
The Four Images are Green Dragon, White Tiger, Vermilion Bird, and Dark Warrior.
Cinnabar-mercury is mercury drawn from cinnabar.
Lead-silver is silver drawn from lead.
Fire-timing refers to the fire of true yang and the seasonal tokens of its rhythm.

Master Pingshu admonished that scholars recklessly misidentify:
the lungs as Metal, the liver as Wood, the kidneys as Water,
the heart as Fire, and the spleen as Earth.
They further assign the liver to the Green Dragon, the lungs to the White Tiger,
the heart to the Vermilion Bird, and the kidneys to the Dark Warrior.
Such conflations of the Five Phases and Four Images
render the refinement of the Golden Elixir utterly indiscriminate,
unable to distinguish cinnabar-mercury from lead-silver.
Nor are these Five Phases and Four Images to be sought outside the body—
for lead and cinnabar are tangible substances,
just as the five viscera possess tangible forms.
How then can they serve as the foundation for attaining the Dao?

Only by discerning the intangible function within tangible form
does one progress from the coarse to the refined,
transcending the mundane to enter the sacred,
thereby grasping the secret of lead and mercury.
Yet even if one recognizes cinnabar and black lead,
ignorance of fire-timing renders such knowledge idle.
How much worse to lack understanding entirely,
yet mislead others with false instruction—
a case of the blind leading the blind,
with no hope of escape.
Can such a heart endure its own indifference?

---

Heaven and Earth alternate between closure and openness;
dawn and dusk must recognize the cycles of inception and obscurity.
Like spokes converging at the hub, like rivers flowing to the sea—
the marvel lies in the art of withdrawal and addition.

Attain the One, and ten thousand affairs are complete;
cease dividing east from west, south from north.
Reduce and refine with utmost care, guarding prior merit—
the Treasure of Life must not be trifled with.

When Heaven and Earth unite, it is called *Peace* (泰),
where upper yin meets lower yang.
When they fail to unite, it is called *Stagnation* (否),
where upper yang meets lower yin.
*Cloud and Thunder* (屯) signifies the inception of difficulty,
as the noble one weaves the warp and weft of creation—
things in their nascent struggle must not be harmed.
*Youthful Folly* (蒙) depicts a spring emerging from the mountain’s base,
as the noble one nurtures virtue through resolute action—
the spring’s first flow must be guided with innocence to cultivate integrity.

These four hexagrams’ meanings,
when applied as metaphors for the Golden Elixir,
are perfectly apt.
Yet some divide the sixty-four hexagrams into thirty days,
designating *Heaven* (乾), *Earth* (坤), *Water* (坎), and *Fire* (離) as the furnace and crucible—
how forced and contrived!

They fail to grasp that the Dao consists of the interplay of yin and yang,
while the work lies in the alternations of *Stagnation* (否), *Peace* (泰), *Inception* (屯), and *Folly* (蒙).
In the language of the Golden Elixir,
all depends on the essence of yin-yang union.
If Heaven remains Heaven and Earth remains Earth,
*Stagnation* persists, unyielding—
how then can they unite as *Peace*?
Without such union, how can yin and yang embody the Dao?
How can the Great Medicine become the Elixir?

As for morning as *Inception* (屯) and evening as *Folly* (蒙),
this signifies vigilance in preservation—
ever mindful of the difficulty of inception and the nurturing of innocence,
never allowing a single stray thought or moment of indulgence.
Vigilant where unseen, fearful where unheard,
one remains unwavering in the fleeting moments of dawn and dusk.
Through such cultivation,
spokes converge at the hub like a chariot in motion, flawless and unbroken,
like water flowing in its course, turning myriad bends yet ever eastward.
Thus the mechanism of the primordial qi of True Unity
resonates in perfect accord with the celestial rhythm,
withdrawal and addition harmonizing the workings of Heaven’s design.

Having attained this Treasure of Life,
one must uphold its fullness and preserve its achievement.
As *Baopuzi* states:
“If a person can guard the One, the One will guard the person.
If a person cannot guard the One, the One will depart.”
Is this not why the Treasure of Life must not be trifled with?

---

At the Winter Solstice, the yang returns in *Recovery* (復);
every thirty days, a yang line is added.
In the moon’s cycle, *Recovery* (復) appears at dawn on the new moon,
while at full moon, *Heaven* (乾) culminates before yielding to *Encounter* (姤).
The sun, too, marks the turning of cold and heat—
yang revives at midnight, while at noon,
the image of conception heralds the advent of yin.
Only in the alchemy of the Elixir does one discern the mysteries of dawn and dusk.

A year comprises three hundred and sixty days,
with six yin and six yang lines waxing and waning,
clustered within the hexagrams’ configurations.
There is the Winter Solstice of the year,
the Winter Solstice of the month,
and the Winter Solstice of the day.
Six positions intermingle, a single yang stirring amidst them—
the twelve hexagrams complete,
and the celestial Dao becomes luminous,
the fire-timing of the celestial cycle fulfilled.

In the year’s cycle, yang revives at the *zi* hour of the Winter Solstice,
the eleventh month governed by *Earth-Thunder Recovery* (地雷復),
marked by one yang line.
The twelfth month, governed by the *chou* branch,
is ruled by *Earth-Marsh Approach* (地澤臨),
with two yang lines.
The first month, governed by the *yin* branch,
is ruled by *Earth-Heaven Peace* (地天泰),
with three yang lines.
Each month, a hexagram shifts every thirty days,
advancing the fire-token—
thus every thirty days, a yang line is added,
completing the annual cycle of hexagrammatic qi.

To cluster the year’s months into the Winter Solstice of the month:
a month has thirty days, each day twelve hours,
totaling three hundred and sixty hours—
equivalent to a year’s three hundred and sixty days.
The first day corresponds to *Recovery* (復),
every two and a half days to *Water* (坎),
until the fifteenth day, when *Heaven* (乾) appears as pure yang.
Yet when yang reaches its zenith, yin arises—
on the sixteenth day, the full moon,
governed by *Heaven-Wind Encounter* (天風姤),
the fire-token retreats as yin grows and yang wanes.
This is what is meant by “at full moon, *Heaven* (乾) culminates before yielding to *Encounter* (姤)”—
the daily hexagrams of the month mirror the annual celestial cycle.

As for clustering the year’s days into the Winter Solstice of the day:
a day’s twelve hours divide into the nodes of yin-yang ascent and descent.
The initial *zi* hour marks the Winter Solstice, when yang revives;
the *wu* hour marks the Summer Solstice, when yin revives.
Each two-hour period corresponds to a hexagram,
with *Recovery* (復) and *Encounter* (姤) marking the inception of yin-yang advance and retreat,
and *Heaven* (乾) and *Earth* (坤) marking their transformation.
Day and night revolve within the hundred *ke*,
the workings of spirit transposed from days to hours—
likewise mirroring the annual cycle of hexagrammatic qi.

chunks.original_text: 修真之士外立表漏以测天运之晷刻，内修真一以验本身之刻漏。 既知一年之冬至、夏至如此，又知一月之冬、夏二至如此，又知一日之冬、夏二至如此。 体天法象，洞知昏晓，神清气爽，百脉和畅，虽未能升举冲天，岂不胜似荒迷酒色、与鬼为邻者哉。 此与天地合德，与日月合明，与四时合叔，与鬼神合其吉凶者是也，岂异端曲学乎。 西江月 德行修逾八百，阴功积满三千。 均齐物我与亲冤，始合神仙本愿。 虎兕刀兵不害，无常火宅难牵。 宝符降后去朝天，稳驾鸾舆凤辈。 天得一以清，地得一以宁，人得一以灵。 吾儒之道一以贯之，释氏之教一心即佛，道家之法真一常存。 今平叔言八百三千之异何耶，吁，道体则一，道用则殊。 亘古今，穷天地，推万有之伙，究象数之烦，道无往而不在，惟修真者无一不洞晓於心，践履於己，如四端万善之皆备，六度万行之兼修，阴功阳德真积力久，物我亲充同仁一视，始合神仙本愿。 古语曰：欲修仙道，先尽人道是也。 推是心以往，则祸息自消，虎兕刀兵所不能害，跳出世网无常，火宅所不能牵，上合天心，太一赐召，如张天师冲举，许旌阳上升，皆是天降宝符，诏归金阙，鸾车凤笔稳驾紫宸，此修真奉道之效，大丈夫功成名遂之秋也，有志者可不勉旃。 紫阳真人悟真篇讲义春之七竟
chunks.translated_text:
Those who cultivate the Dao set up gnomons and clepsydras externally to measure the celestial movements of the sun’s shadow, while internally they refine the True One to verify the clepsydra’s flow within their own bodies. Having grasped the Winter and Summer Solstices of the year in this way, they likewise comprehend the two solstices of the month and the two solstices of the day. Embracing the patterns of Heaven and emulating its images, they penetrate the mysteries of dusk and dawn, their spirits clear and their qi fresh, their hundred vessels harmonious and unobstructed. Though they may not yet ascend and soar to the heavens, how can this not surpass those who, lost in dissipation and lust, dwell as neighbors to ghosts?

This is to unite one’s virtue with Heaven and Earth, to merge one’s radiance with the sun and moon, to align with the sequence of the four seasons, and to harmonize with the auspices and omens of spirits and gods—how could this be heretical or distorted learning?

*To the tune of* West River Moon:
Virtue cultivated surpasses eight hundred,
Hidden merits accumulated fill three thousand.
Equalizing self and others, friend and foe,
Only then does one fulfill the original vow of immortals.

Tigers, rhinos, blades, and weapons cannot harm,
The inescapable fire-house of impermanence cannot entangle.
After the treasure talisman descends, one ascends to pay homage to Heaven,
Steadily riding the phoenix-drawn chariot of the luan-bird.

Heaven attains the One and becomes clear,
Earth attains the One and becomes tranquil,
Humankind attains the One and becomes numinous.
Our Confucian Way is threaded through by the One,
The Buddha’s teaching is that the One Mind is Buddha,
The Daoist method is that the True One abides forever.

Now, why does Master Ping Shu speak of the disparity between eight hundred and three thousand? Alas, the essence of the Dao is one, yet its manifestations differ. Spanning ancient and modern, pervading Heaven and Earth, encompassing the myriad existences, exhausting the complexities of images and numbers—the Dao is present wherever one turns. Only those who cultivate the Dao fully comprehend it in their hearts and embody it in their conduct. Whether it be the Four Beginnings and ten thousand virtues all perfected, or the Six Perfections and ten thousand practices jointly cultivated, hidden merits and manifest virtues truly accumulated through long effort, equalizing self and others, friend and foe with impartial benevolence—only then does one fulfill the original vow of immortals.

As the ancient saying goes: “To cultivate the Dao of immortality, first fulfill the Dao of humanity.” Extending this mind onward, calamities naturally dissipate, and tigers, rhinos, blades, and weapons cannot harm. One leaps free from the world’s net of impermanence, and the fire-house cannot entangle. Aligning with the will of Heaven, the Great One bestows a summons. Like Master Zhang who ascended in broad daylight, or Master Xu who rose to the heavens, all received the Heaven-sent treasure talisman, the imperial edict to return to the Golden Gates, steadily riding the luan-carriage and phoenix-pennant to the Purple Palace. Such is the fruition of cultivating the Dao and upholding the Way—the season when the great man’s work is accomplished and his name is achieved. Those with aspiration, can you not strive onward?

*Commentary on the* Wondrous Realization *of Master Ziyang, Seventh Chapter of Spring, concludes.*

the *wu* hour marks the Summer Solstice, when yin revives.
Each two-hour period corresponds to a hexagram,
with *Recovery* (復) and *Encounter* (姤) marking the inception of yin-yang advance and retreat,
and *Heaven* (乾) and *Earth* (坤) marking their transformation.
Day and night revolve within the hundred *ke*,
the workings of spirit transposed from days to hours—
likewise mirroring the annual cycle of hexagrammatic qi.
